Knowledge Point: A \isi{noun phrase} (NP) consists minimally of a noun or a \isi{pronoun}, but may contain additional elements, such as \is{possession} possessive markers, \isi{adjective}s, \isi{numeral}s, or \isi{determiner}s. The canonical order of elements in an Ulwa NP is given in \REF{ex:phrase:1}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The \isi{noun phrase} given in \REF{ex:phrase:2} illustrates all these elements occurring together. The \isi{head noun} is indicated in \textbf{bold}.
Content 1: \gsrc nïnji \textbf{lamndu} ambi kwe anda | \gll nï-nji \textbf{lamndu} ambi kwe anda | \gls 1SG-POSS pig big one SG.DIST | \glt `that one big pig of mine’

Subsection: The head of the noun phrase\label{sec:9.1.1
Knowledge Point: The \isi{head} of a \isi{noun phrase} need not be a prototypical noun. It may, instead, be an \isi{adjective} functioning as a noun \REF{ex:phrase:3} (see \sectref{sec:5.3} on substantive uses of \isi{adjective}s). Similarly, like \isi{personal pronoun}s, \isi{possessive pronoun}s (\sectref{sec:6.2}) may also function as the \isi{head} of an NP \REF{ex:phrase:4}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ambi} \textbf{anda} wa lolop man. | \gll \textbf{ambi} anda wa lolop ma-n | \gls big SG.DIST just just go-IPFV | \glt `That big [man] just goes around.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï \textbf{nïnji ngalat} unanda. | \gll nï \textbf{nï-nji} ngala=tï u=na-nda | \gls 1SG 1SG-POSS PL.PROX=take 2SG=give-IRR | \glt `I will give mine to you.’

Knowledge Point: As discussed in \sectref{sec:7.1} and \sectref{sec:7.2}, \isi{subject marker}s and \isi{object marker}s do not always occur in NPs that function as subjects or as objects. When they do occur, however, they mark their respective NPs for \isi{number}. The three \isi{number} categories in Ulwa are \isi{singular}, \isi{dual}, and \isi{plural} (\sectref{sec:7.1}--\sectref{sec:7.3}). Whereas the category of \isi{dual} is never employed when there are three or more referents, the category of \isi{plural} is sometimes found even when there are exactly two referents, as in \REF{ex:phrase:5}.
Content 1: \gsrc Wonmbi \textbf{ndïtumulka}. | \gll wonmbi \textbf{ndï}=tumul-ka | \gls tusk 3PL=bend-let | \glt `[They] bent the tusks.’

Knowledge Point: Multiple \isi{adjective}s may occur within a single NP. When there are multiple \isi{adjective}s, they simply stack up after the \isi{head noun} (and before any \isi{determiner}s), as seen in \REF{ex:phrase:6} and \REF{ex:phrase:7}.
Content 1: \gsrc Wapa \textbf{ambi tembi} ndawe nï mat inde. | \gll wapa \textbf{ambi} \textbf{tembi} anda-we nï ma=tï inda-e | \gls leaf big bad SG.DIST-PART.INT 1SG 3SG.OBJ=take walk-IPFV | \glt `That big, bad leaf alone -- I’m taking it.’
Content 2: \gsrc Tïmbïl \textbf{ambi nïpat ngata} maytana mane. | \gll tïmbïl \textbf{ambi} \textbf{nïpat} \textbf{ngata} ma=ita-na ma-n-e | \gls fence big giant grand 3SG.OBJ=build-IRR go-IPFV-DEP | \glt `[You] are going to build a big, huge, giant fence.’

Knowledge Point: Two noun phrases may be in \isi{apposition} to each other, as in \REF{ex:phrase:8}. Here, the two NPs in \isi{apposition} are the \isi{compound noun} wot yana ‘younger sister’ and the \isi{proper noun} Sinanam, a woman’s name. Each NP serves as the \isi{singular} grammatical object of the verb na- ‘give’.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Wot yana Sinanam} manana. | \gll \textbf{wot} \textbf{yana} \textbf{Sinanam} ma=na-na | \gls younger woman [name] 3SG.OBJ=give-PFV | \glt `[He] gave it to the younger sister Sinanam.’

Knowledge Point: The possessive \isi{suffix} \textit{{}-nji} \textsc{`poss’} affixes to \isi{pronoun}s and \isi{determiner}s to create \isi{possessive pronoun}s and possessive \isi{demonstrative}s \sectref{sec:6.2}. These so-formed \isi{possessive pronoun}s may in turn occur in NPs (following the \isi{possessor} argument) to indicate \isi{possession}. Sentences \REF{ex:phrase:9} through \REF{ex:phrase:12} illustrate \isi{possession} marked on full NPs. The \isi{possessor} is indicated in \textbf{bold}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Itom manji} lamndu mï nip. | \gll \textbf{itom} \textbf{ma-nji} lamndu mï ni-p | \gls father 3SG.OBJ-POSS pig 3SG.SUBJ die-PFV | \glt `Father’s pig died.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Nïnji atuma manji} aweta mï tembip. | \gll \textbf{nï-nji} \textbf{atuma} \textbf{ma-nji} aweta mï tembi=p | \gls 1SG-POSS older.brother 3SG.OBJ-POSS friend 3SG.SUBJ bad=COP | \glt `My older brother’s friend is sick.’

Knowledge Point: To intensify \isi{possessor} NPs that contain \isi{possessive pronoun}s, the modifier wo ‘very own’ may be added. Whereas the \isi{possessive pronoun} precedes the \isi{head noun}, the \isi{emphatic} modifier wo ‘very own’ follows it, as in examples \REF{ex:phrase:13} through \REF{ex:phrase:16}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Manji} tïn \textbf{wo} lamndu masap. | \gll \textbf{ma-nji} tïn \textbf{wo} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls 3SG.OBJ-POSS dog own pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `His very own dog killed the pig.’
Content 2: \gsrc Yetani \textbf{lanji} \textbf{wo}. | \gll Yetani \textbf{ala-nji} \textbf{wo} | \gls Yamen PL.DIST-POSS own | \glt `[He was] the Yamen people’s very own [ancestor].’

Knowledge Point: Another means of signaling that an NP has a \isi{possessor} role is the \isi{oblique-marker} \isi{enclitic} =n \textsc{‘obl'} (\sectref{sec:11.4.1}). This strategy is mainly limited to pronominal \isi{possessor}s. In such constructions, the \isi{pronoun} or \isi{demonstrative} marked with =n \textsc{‘obl'} is the \isi{possessor} of the NP that immediately follows, as in examples \REF{ex:phrase:17} through \REF{ex:phrase:20}.
Content 1: \gsrc Upan nungol ndïn \textbf{nïn} ani up. | \gll upan nungol ndï=\textbf{n} nï=n ani u-p | \gls fish.species child 3PL=OBL 1SG=OBL bilum put-PFV | \glt `[She] put some small fish in my bilum [= string bag].’
Content 2: \gsrc Atana mï liyu matïn mat \textbf{ambïn} ame menlïp. | \gll atana mï li-u ma=tï-n ma=tï ambï=\textbf{n} ame ma=in-lï-p | \gls older.sister 3SG.SUBJ down-from 3SG.OBJ=take-PFV 3SG.OBJ=take SG.REFL=OBL basket 3SG.OBJ=in-put-PFV | \glt `The older sister got him down and put him in her basket.’

Knowledge Point: See \sectref{sec:11.4.2} for other \isi{case}-like uses of the \isi{oblique marker}. It may be noted here that there is some overlap in function between the \isi{oblique marker} and the possessive marker. Just as the \isi{oblique marker} =n \textsc{‘obl'} can function very much like a possessive marker, \isi{possessive pronoun}s marked with -nji \textsc{‘poss'} can serve \isi{oblique}-like functions -- namely, they may indicate a beneficiary, as in sentences \REF{ex:phrase:21}, \REF{ex:phrase:22}, and \REF{ex:phrase:23}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï i \textbf{ngunji} mundu ilum kuma wananda. | \gll nï i ngun-\textbf{nji} mundu ilum kuma wana-nda | \gls 1SG go.PFV 2DU-POSS food little some cook-IRR | \glt `I will come and cook some food for you.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ndïnji} na tïna mbïlop. | \gll ndï-\textbf{nji} na tï-na mbï-lo-p | \gls 3PL-POSS talk take-IRR here-go-PFV | \glt `[They] came here to have a talk for them [= their children].’
Content 3: \gsrc Nï \textbf{manji} ana mat manana. | \gll nï ma-\textbf{nji} ana ma=tï ma=na-na | \gls 1SG 3SG.OBJ-POSS grass.skirt 3SG.OBJ=take 3SG.OBJ=give-PFV | \glt `I gave her a grass skirt.’

Knowledge Point: Possession can also be indicated with a \isi{non-subject marker} (\sectref{sec:7.3}), without any additional possessive or \isi{oblique} marking. In such instances, these “\isi{object marker}s” do not seem to be \isi{clitic}s: they are not necessarily \isi{phonological}ly dependent on the following word. Like the \isi{oblique-marker} strategy, this strategy is mainly limited to pronominal \isi{possessor}s, as in examples \REF{ex:phrase:24} through \REF{ex:phrase:28}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ma} yawa mï i makalilïpe. | \gll \textbf{ma} yawa mï i ma=kali-lï-p-e | \gls 3SG.OBJ uncle 3SG.SUBJ go.PFV 3SG.OBJ=send-put-PFV-DEP | \glt `Her uncle went and sent her.’
Content 2: \gsrc I lïmndï \textbf{min} luwa ala. | \gll i lïmndï \textbf{min} luwa ala | \gls go.PFV eye 3DU place for | \glt `[He] went and saw their place.’\footnote{It is possible that the \isi{oblique}-marking strategy is being used here, but that a sequence of /nn/ resulting from the final /n/ of the \isi{dual} pronominal form and the /=n/ that is the \isi{oblique marker} has \isi{degeminate}d.} [ulwa001_10:15]’

Knowledge Point: Occasionally, \isi{possession} is indicated without any marking. Rather, the \isi{possessum} simply follows the \isi{possessor}. This strategy is mainly restricted to phrases with \isi{proper noun} \isi{possessor}s, but there are a few known examples with \isi{common noun} \isi{possessor}s as well (all are \isi{kinship} terms). Sentences \REF{ex:phrase:29} through \REF{ex:phrase:34} illustrate this \isi{juxtaposition} method.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Yawana} numan ngusuwa nda | \gll \textbf{Yawana} numan ngusuwa anda | \gls [name] husband poor SG.DIST | \glt `Yawana’s poor husband’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï ango wa i \textbf{nïnji itom} wandam alo lop. | \gll nï ango wa i \textbf{nï-nji} \textbf{itom} wandam ala=u lo-p | \gls 1SG NEG village go.PFV 1SG-POSS father jungle PL.DIST=from go-PFV | \glt `I haven’t gone to the village, gone around in my father’s jungles.’

Knowledge Point: In such constructions it appears to be common for the \isi{possessed} \isi{phrase} to contain a postnominal \isi{demonstrative} -- for example, ‘these children of Manama’ in \REF{ex:phrase:31} -- although this is not mandatory.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï wa man mïka \textbf{Manama} nungol ngalat: … | \gll nï wa ma=n mïka \textbf{Manama} nungol ngala=ta | \gls 1SG just 3SG.OBJ=OBL thus [name] child PL.PROX=say | \glt `I just, like, told Manama’s children: …’

Knowledge Point: In addition to these methods of indicating \isi{possession} with noun phrases, it is possible to indicate \isi{possession} with \isi{verb phrase}s. These \isi{verb phrase}s function in such instances as \isi{relative clause}s (\sectref{sec:12.3}), as in \REF{ex:phrase:35}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Kaytape} anapa mï | \gll [\textbf{Kayta=p-e}] anapa mï | \gls [[name]=COP-DEP] sister 3SG.SUBJ | \glt `Kayta’s sister’

Knowledge Point: These \isi{verb phrase}s may in turn be \isi{nominalize}d, as in examples \REF{ex:phrase:36} and \REF{ex:phrase:37}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Lucypen} anda. | \gll \textbf{Lucy=p-en} anda | \gls [name]=COP-NMLZ SG.DIST | \glt `That [pot] is Lucy’s.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Albertpen} maka yena inom mï maka mu kumat nïnana. | \gll \textbf{Albert=p-en} maka yena inom mï maka mu kuma=tï nï=na-na | \gls [name]=COP-NMLZ thus woman mother 3SG.SUBJ thus seed some=take 1SG=give-PFV | \glt `Albert’s wife’s mother, like, gave me some seeds.’

Knowledge Point: Noun phrases may serve a number of grammatical functions within a clause: the subject, the object of a verb, the \isi{object of a postposition}, or part of an \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase} marked by the \isi{oblique marker} =n ‘\textsc{obl}’ (\chapref{sec:11}). In addition to these clause-internal functions, noun phrases may occasionally stand alone as entire clauses. In this use, the grandeur of an event is stressed, the \isi{predicate} itself being merely implied, as in \REF{ex:phrase:38} and \REF{ex:phrase:39}.
Content 1: \gsrc Min map. \textbf{Mïnda wandam}! | \gll min ma=p \textbf{mïnda} \textbf{wandam} | \gls 3DU 3SG.OBJ=be banana jungle | \glt `The two were staying there. Banana garden!’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: A verb \isi{phrase} (VP) consists minimally of a verb, a non-verbal element with \isi{copular enclitic} (\sectref{sec:10.2}), or a \isi{postposition} functioning as a verb (\sectref{sec:8.2}). In some instances, a VP may also contain a \isi{noun phrase} (NP) or a \isi{postpositional phrase}s (PP). The order of potential elements of the Ulwa VP is given in \REF{ex:phrase:40}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The phrases in \REF{ex:phrase:41} and \REF{ex:phrase:42} are both \isi{intransitive}, whereas those in \REF{ex:phrase:43} and \REF{ex:phrase:44} are both \isi{transitive}. The phrases in \REF{ex:phrase:42} and \REF{ex:phrase:44} both contain \isi{postpositional phrase}s, whereas those in \REF{ex:phrase:41} and \REF{ex:phrase:43} do not.
Content 1: \gsrc man | \gll ma-n | \gls go-IPFV | \glt `is going’
Content 2: \gsrc im maya man | \gll im ma=iya ma-n | \gls tree 3SG.OBJ=toward go-IPFV | \glt `is going toward the tree’
Content 3: \gsrc utam mawanap | \gll utam ma=wana-p | \gls yam 3SG.OBJ=cook-PFV | \glt `cooked the yam’
Content 4: \gsrc apïn mawat mawanap | \gll apïn ma=wat ma=wana-p | \gls fire 3SG.OBJ=atop 3SG.OBJ=cook-PFV | \glt `cooked the yam on the fire’
Content 5: \gsrc im maya man | \gll im ma=iya ma-n | \gls tree 3SG.OBJ=toward go-IPFV | \glt `is going toward the tree’
Content 6: \gsrc apïn mawat mawanap | \gll apïn ma=wat ma=wana-p | \gls fire 3SG.OBJ=atop 3SG.OBJ=cook-PFV | \glt `cooked the yam on the fire’
Content 8: \gsrc utam mawanap | \gll utam ma=wana-p | \gls yam 3SG.OBJ=cook-PFV | \glt `cooked the yam’

Knowledge Point: In \sectref{sec:4.14} it was shown that \isi{compound verb} forms can be constructed with \isi{postposition}al or nominal elements (in additional to at least one verbal component). Some \isi{compound} verbs containing nominal elements can actually be \isi{discontinuous} -- that is, words may intervene between the nominal component and the verbal component, as illustrated by \REF{ex:phrase:55}.
Content 1: \gsrc An \textbf{kïkal} inom itom \textbf{ndïwana}. | \gll an \textbf{kïkal} inom itom ndï=\textbf{wana} | \gls 1PL.EXCL ear mother father 3PL=feel | \glt `We listened to our parents.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:phrase:55}, the verb wana- ‘feel, taste, sense, think’ combines with kïkal ‘ear’ to form the the \isi{compound} kïkalwana- ‘hear’, which thus consists of two separable parts. The object of the verb occurs between the two elements kïkal ‘ear’ and wana- ‘feel’.
Content 1: \gsrc An \textbf{kïkal} inom itom \textbf{ndïwana}. | \gll an \textbf{kïkal} inom itom ndï=\textbf{wana} | \gls 1PL.EXCL ear mother father 3PL=feel | \glt `We listened to our parents.’

Knowledge Point: It may first be demonstrated how wana- ‘feel’ can function as a verb on its own, with a variety of related meanings, as in \REF{ex:phrase:45}, \REF{ex:phrase:46}, and \REF{ex:phrase:47}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{wana} Raten ndï ita. | \gll nï \textbf{wana} Raten ndï i-ta | \gls 1SG feel [place] 3PL go.PFV-COND | \glt `I thought that the Raten people would come.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ankam \textbf{mawane} mambi … | \gll ankam ma=\textbf{wana}-e ma-ambi | \gls person 3SG.OBJ=feel-DEP 3SG.OBJ-TOP | \glt `As for the person who tastes it …’

Knowledge Point: Thus, wana- ‘feel’ can function either as an \isi{intransitive} verb introducing a clausal complement \REF{ex:phrase:45} or as a \isi{transitive} verb, as in \REF{ex:phrase:46} and \REF{ex:phrase:47}. The form wana- ‘feel’, however, can combine with a nominal element to create a new meaning. For example, sentence \REF{ex:phrase:48} illustrates the noun-plus-verb \isi{compound} nambïtwana- ‘smell’, which here takes as its \isi{direct object} the \isi{pronoun} nï= ‘1\textsc{sg}’.\footnote{The \isi{compound} nambïtwana- ‘smell (\isi{transitive})’ consists of nambït ‘odor’ and wana- ‘sense’ (i.e., ‘sense odor’).}
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{wana} Raten ndï ita. | \gll nï \textbf{wana} Raten ndï i-ta | \gls 1SG feel [place] 3PL go.PFV-COND | \glt `I thought that the Raten people would come.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ankam \textbf{mawane} mambi … | \gll ankam ma=\textbf{wana}-e ma-ambi | \gls person 3SG.OBJ=feel-DEP 3SG.OBJ-TOP | \glt `As for the person who tastes it …’
Content 4: \gsrc Mï \textbf{nïnambïtwana} ko anmbu i. | \gll mï nï=\textbf{nambït-wana} ko an-mbï-u i | \gls 3SG.SUBJ 1SG=odor-feel just out-here-from go.PFV | \glt `It smelled me and just went out from there.’

Knowledge Point: The verb inakawana- ‘think’ is a \isi{compound} that contains an entire \isi{postpositional phrase} (including a noun).\footnote{The \isi{compound} inakawana- ‘think’ consists of ina ‘liver [the seat of reason]’, ka ‘at, in, on’, and wana- ‘feel’, (i.e., ‘feel in [one’s] mind’).} Its use is illustrated by examples \REF{ex:phrase:49} and \REF{ex:phrase:50}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï i atay mawap \textbf{inakawanap}. | \gll mï i ata-i ma=wap \textbf{ina-ka-wana}-p | \gls 3SG.SUBJ go.PFV up-go.PFV 3SG.OBJ=be.PST liver-at-feel-PFV | \glt `He went, went up, stayed there, and thought.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï \textbf{inakawana} nï unul mbïpïta … | \gll nï \textbf{ina-ka-wana} nï un=ul mbï-p-ta | \gls 1SG liver-at-feel 1SG 2PL=with here-be{-cond} | \glt `So I thought: if I stay here with you …’

Knowledge Point: The verb inakawana- ‘think’ may take as an object the topic about which one thinks \REF{ex:phrase:51}. Here, the object occurs before the entire \isi{compound} (i.e., this is not a \isi{separable verb}).
Content 1: \gsrc Atana nda nipe ndï ango \textbf{ninakawan}. | \gll atana anda ni-p-e ndï ango nï=\textbf{ina-ka-wana} | \gls older.sister SG.DIST die-PFV-DEP 3PL NEG 1SG=liver-at-feel | \glt `When that older sister died, they didn’t think of me.’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{compound} kïkalwana- ‘hear’, on the other hand, can be separated when it has an object. First, it may be seen that, when there is no object, the nominal element kïkal ‘ear’ occurs immediately before the verbal element. Examples \REF{ex:phrase:52} and \REF{ex:phrase:53} illustrate kïkalwana- ‘hear’ functioning as an \isi{intransitive} verb (meaning something like ‘listen’).
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï \textbf{kïkalwana} ngunaniya ita. | \gll ndï \textbf{kïkal-wana} ngunan=iya i-ta | \gls 3PL ear-feel 1DU.INCL=toward go.PFV-COND | \glt `If only they would listen and come to us.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ango \textbf{kïkalwana}. | \gll ango \textbf{kïkal-wana} | \gls NEG ear-feel | \glt `[They] don’t listen.’

Knowledge Point: However, when kïkalwana- ‘hear’ is \isi{transitive}, we see that its component parts are separable. The nominal element kïkal ‘ear’ is separate from the \isi{verb stem} wana- ‘feel’, with the object of the verb occurring between these two parts, as in examples \REF{ex:phrase:54} and \REF{ex:phrase:56}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï mbi nïmal mbïpen ndï \textbf{kïkal} na \textbf{mawana}. | \gll ndï mbï-i nïmal mbï-p-en ndï \textbf{kïkal} na ma=\textbf{wana} | \gls 3PL here-go.PFV river here-be{-nmlz} 3PL ear talk 3SG.OBJ=feel | \glt `Those who came here and stay here at the river would hear the message.’
Content 2: \gsrc U \textbf{kïkal} \textbf{mawane}. | \gll u \textbf{kïkal} ma=\textbf{wana}-e | \gls 2SG ear 3SG.OBJ=feel-DEP | \glt `You heard it.’

Knowledge Point: Viewed from an alternative perspective, such verbal constructions can be said to be lacking “incorporation” rather than exhibiting “separation”. In this view, sentences such as \REF{ex:phrase:54} and \REF{ex:phrase:56} would be said to have “unincorporated” verbal structures.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï mbi nïmal mbïpen ndï \textbf{kïkal} na \textbf{mawana}. | \gll ndï mbï-i nïmal mbï-p-en ndï \textbf{kïkal} na ma=\textbf{wana} | \gls 3PL here-go.PFV river here-be{-nmlz} 3PL ear talk 3SG.OBJ=feel | \glt `Those who came here and stay here at the river would hear the message.’
Content 2: \gsrc U \textbf{kïkal} \textbf{mawane}. | \gll u \textbf{kïkal} ma=\textbf{wana}-e | \gls 2SG ear 3SG.OBJ=feel-DEP | \glt `You heard it.’

Knowledge Point: In constructions with \isi{separable verb}s, the first element always appears at the absolute beginning of the verb \isi{phrase}. \isi{Postposition}s, which are also properly constituents of VPs, appear after the first element, as in \REF{ex:phrase:57}, where kïkal ‘ear’ is the first element in the \isi{separable verb} construction.
Content 1: \gsrc Ango yeta ndï \textbf{kïkal} nïn u na \textbf{ngalawan}. | \gll ango yeta ndï \textbf{kïkal} nï=n u na ngala=\textbf{wana} | \gls NEG man 3PL ear 1SG=OBL from talk PL.PROX=feel | \glt `No men hear these stories from me.’

Knowledge Point: Such \isi{separable verb} constructions are especially common with \is{perception verb} verbs of perception. Thus, verbs of seeing function similarly to this verb of hearing. Such ‘seeing’ constructions combine the word lïmndï ‘eye’ with the irregular \isi{suppletive} verb ala- {\textasciitilde} andï- ‘see’. If there is an expressed object, it occurs between these two elements. Example \REF{ex:phrase:58} demonstrates an \isi{intransitive} use of this verb.
Content 1: \gsrc An ambi nape \textbf{lïmndï ala}. | \gll an ambi na-p-e \textbf{lïmndï} \textbf{ala} | \gls 1PL.EXCL big DETR-be{-dep} eye see | \glt `When we had gotten big, [we] looked around.’

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{ex:phrase:59} through \REF{ex:phrase:63}, on the other hand, are \isi{transitive} sentences, which illustrate the separable element lïmndï ‘eye’ occurring before the \isi{direct object} of the verb.
Content 1: \gsrc Unan ango \textbf{lïmndï} ankam \textbf{ala}. | \gll unan ango \textbf{lïmndï} ankam \textbf{ala} | \gls 1PL.INCL NEG eye person see | \glt `We haven’t seen anyone.’
Content 2: \gsrc Una \textbf{lïmndï} mangusuwa \textbf{andïna}. | \gll unan \textbf{lïmndï} ma-ngusuwa \textbf{andï-na} | \gls 1PL.INCL eye 3SG.OBJ-poor see-IRR | \glt `We will see the poor thing.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:phrase:64}, the first element lïmndï ‘eye’ precedes a \isi{direct object} NP that itself contains a VP.
Content 1: \gsrc Una \textbf{lïmndï} makape i \textbf{mandïm}. | \gll unan \textbf{lïmndï} [maka=p-e] i ma=\textbf{andï-m} | \gls 1PL.INCL eye [thus=COP-DEP] way 3SG.OBJ=see-PFV | \glt `We’ve seen this kind of behavior.’

Knowledge Point: Crucial for the argument that the nouns kïkal ‘ear’ and lïmndï ‘eye’ are truly (separable) parts of \isi{compound verb}s is the fact that they never receive \isi{postposition}s or \isi{oblique marker}s in these constructions. That is, they cannot be interpreted as belonging to other phrases. For example, constructions such as \REF{ex:phrase:65} are never found.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{kïkaln(ï)} mawana | \gll kïkal=\textbf{n(ï)} ma=wana | \gls ear=OBL 3SG.OBJ=feel | \glt ‘sense with ear’

Knowledge Point: Expressions of visual perception can also be formed with other verbs \is{perception verb}, such as lï- ‘put’ and uta- ‘grind’. In all instances, the nominal element lïmndï ‘eye’ behaves the same -- that is, it never receives any \isi{oblique} marking, as illustrated by \REF{ex:phrase:66}, \REF{ex:phrase:67}, and \REF{ex:phrase:68}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï \textbf{lïmndï malïp}. | \gll mï \textbf{lïmndï} ma=\textbf{lï}-p | \gls 3SG.SUBJ eye 3SG.OBJ=put-PFV | \glt `She watched it.’
Content 2: \gsrc Mï ndala wonka \textbf{lïmndï} manji asiya \textbf{ndute}. | \gll mï ndï=ala won-ka \textbf{lïmndï} ma-nji asiya ndï=\textbf{uta}-e | \gls 3SG.SUBJ 3PL=from cut-let eye 3SG.OBJ-POSS string 3PL=grind-IPFV | \glt `He left them and crossed [the river] and was checking his string traps.’
Content 3: \gsrc Una \textbf{lïmndï} \textbf{ndutape}. | \gll unan \textbf{lïmndï} ndï=\textbf{uta}-p-e | \gls 1PL.INCL eye 3PL=grind-PFV-DEP | \glt `We’ve examined them.’

Knowledge Point: While \is{perception verb} verbs of perception constitute one of the most common subclasses of verbs that exhibit the separable structure, other \isi{compound verb} forms behave similarly. The verb ‘ask’ is composed of the word atwana ‘question’ and some form of a verb of speaking (e.g., ta- ‘say’ or kï- ‘say’) as \isi{discontinuous} elements, with no \isi{oblique} marking on the nominal component atwana ‘question’, as in \REF{ex:phrase:69} and \REF{ex:phrase:70}.\footnote{More information on \isi{reported speech} with na ‘talk’ as a nominal component is provided in \sectref{sec:13.4}.}
Content 1: \gsrc Mï li \textbf{atwana} manji yana \textbf{mat}. | \gll mï li-i \textbf{atwana} ma-nji yana ma=\textbf{ta} | \gls 3SG.SUBJ down-go.PFV question 3SG.OBJ-POSS woman 3SG.OBJ=say | \glt `He went down and asked his wife.’
Content 2: \gsrc Dumngul imba pe i \textbf{atwana} \textbf{ankap}. | \gll Dumngul imba p-e i \textbf{atwana} an=\textbf{kï-p} | \gls [name] night be{-dep} go.PFV question 1PL.EXCL=say-PFV | \glt `Dumngul came at night and asked us.’

Knowledge Point: In a somewhat more complicated fashion, the verb ‘catch, grab, hold’ is formed with the \isi{irregular verb} si- ‘push’, which follows the \isi{discontinuous} element [ikali], which is itself composed of i ‘hand’ and kali ‘send’, and may thus not so clearly be labeled a nominal element. Sentences \REF{ex:phrase:71} and \REF{ex:phrase:72} exemplify this structure.
Content 1: \gsrc Una \textbf{ikali} \textbf{ndïsina}. | \gll unan \textbf{i-kali} ndï=\textbf{si}-na | \gls 1PL.INCL hand-send 3PL=push-IRR | \glt `We can grab them.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ngunan ango \textbf{ikali} ndïn u ani \textbf{kos}. | \gll ngunan ango \textbf{i-kali} ndï=n u ani ko=\textbf{si} | \gls 1DU.INCL NEG hand-send 3PL=OBL from bilum INDF=push | \glt `We haven’t gotten a single bilum [= string bag] from them.’

Subsection: The verbs u- ‘put’, lï- ‘put’, and lumo- ‘put’\label{sec:9.2.2
Knowledge Point: This section covers a small subclass of \isi{separable verb}s involving words with meanings somewhat like \ili{English} put. I say “somewhat like” since there are two important \isi{semantic} distinctions. First, these Ulwa verbs select only two arguments -- that is, they are not three-place \isi{predicate}s. Indeed, they may even be able to function \isi{intransitive}ly as well. Second, the object of these Ulwa verbs is not a \isi{theme} argument, but rather a goal, the place to which a \isi{theme} is put. If a \isi{theme} argument is expressed in a clause, it occurs in an \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase}. One such verb is u- ‘put’, which, as in \REF{ex:phrase:73} and \REF{ex:phrase:74}, takes a \isi{goal} as its object argument.
Content 1: \gsrc Inom mï wa unde iwa lan \textbf{inim andawe}. | \gll inom mï wa unda-e iwa ala=n \textbf{inim} \textbf{anda=aw}-e | \gls mother 3SG.SUBJ just go-DEP basket PL.DIST=OBL water SG.DIST=put.IPFV-DEP | \glt `A woman used to just go around, setting fish traps in the water.’
Content 2: \gsrc Wen \textbf{ndawe}. | \gll we=n \textbf{ndï=aw}-e | \gls sago=OBL 3PL=put.IPFV-DEP | \glt `[They] used to put sago starch in them.’

Subsection: The verbs u- ‘put’, lï- ‘put’, and lumo- ‘put’\label{sec:9.2.2
Knowledge Point: Another major ‘put’ verb is lï- ‘put’, which also takes a \isi{goal} as its \isi{direct object} (and may include a \isi{theme} argument as an \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase}), as in \REF{ex:phrase:76}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Al malpe} mï i. | \gll \textbf{al} \textbf{ma=lï}-p-e mï i | \gls net 3SG.OBJ=put-PFV-DEP 3SG.SUBJ go.PFV | \glt `Having put [the baby] in the mosquito net, she went.’

Subsection: The verbs u- ‘put’, lï- ‘put’, and lumo- ‘put’\label{sec:9.2.2
Knowledge Point: In addition to these two verbs, there is the \isi{defective} \isi{stem} lumo- ‘put’, which seems only to occur in the \isi{perfective} form [lumop] and in \isi{conditional} forms [lumota] and [lumopta]; sometimes, in casual speech, the initial [l-] is lost (i.e., the \isi{stem} may be \is{apheresis} apheresized to [umo-]). It is shown in \REF{ex:phrase:75}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï malimap ndïn \textbf{ame ndïlumop}. | \gll ndï ma=alima-p ndï-n \textbf{ame} \textbf{ndï=lumo}-p | \gls 3PL 3SG.OBJ=beat-PFV 3PL=OBL basket 3PL=put-PFV | \glt `They beat it [= the sago] and put them [= the starch] in the baskets.’

Subsection: The verbs u- ‘put’, lï- ‘put’, and lumo- ‘put’\label{sec:9.2.2
Knowledge Point: These ‘put’ verbs may combine with other elements in \isi{separable verb} constructions. When they do so, the first element resembles verbs in one crucial way: it permits an \isi{object marker}. For example, the (unseparated) verb kalilï- ‘send’ takes as its object that which is sent (i.e., a \isi{theme} argument) \REF{ex:phrase:77}; however, as a \isi{discontinuous} verb, the first element kali ‘send’ takes this \isi{theme} argument as its object, whereas the second element lï- ‘put’ takes as its object the place to which someone or something is sent (i.e., a \isi{goal} argument) \REF{ex:phrase:78}.
Content 1: \gsrc Wot \textbf{makalilïpe}. | \gll wot ma=\textbf{kali-lï}-p-e | \gls younger 3SG.OBJ=send-put-PFV-DEP | \glt `[They] sent the younger brother.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Makali} Nanïmwat \textbf{malp}. | \gll ma=\textbf{kali} Nanïmwat ma=\textbf{lï}-p | \gls 3SG.OBJ=send [place] 3SG.OBJ=put-PFV | \glt `[They] sent him to Nanïmwat [village].’\footnote{This example illustrates yet another peculiarity of the verb lï- ‘put’: the common \isi{elision} of its only \isi{vowel} (\sectref{sec:2.5.9}).} [ulwa002_03:34]’

Subsection: The verbs u- ‘put’, lï- ‘put’, and lumo- ‘put’\label{sec:9.2.2
Knowledge Point: Similarly, the form kuk ‘gather’ may take an \isi{object marker} when appearing with a separable ‘put’ verb. This form mostly appears with the verb u- ‘put’, but may alternatively appear with a blended version containing the element /l/. Examples \REF{ex:phrase:79} and \REF{ex:phrase:80} show an \isi{intransitive} use of the verb.\footnote{According to some terminology, this usage may be considered “\isi{middle voice}”.} Example \REF{ex:phrase:79} lacks the \isi{detransitivizing} marker na- ‘\textsc{detr}’, whereas \REF{ex:phrase:80} includes it (\sectref{sec:13.8.2}).
Content 1: \gsrc Kuma \textbf{kukup}. | \gll kuma \textbf{kuk-u}-p | \gls some gather-put-PFV | \glt `Some gathered.’
Content 2: \gsrc An \textbf{nakukunda}. | \gll an na-\textbf{kuk-u}-nda | \gls 1PL.EXCL DETR-gather-put-IRR | \glt `We would gather.’
Content 4: \gsrc An \textbf{nakukunda}. | \gll an na-\textbf{kuk-u}-nda | \gls 1PL.EXCL DETR-gather-put-IRR | \glt `We would gather.’

Subsection: The verbs u- ‘put’, lï- ‘put’, and lumo- ‘put’\label{sec:9.2.2
Knowledge Point: As a \isi{transitive} verb, however, kuk u- ‘gather’ has as its object that which is ‘gathered’ (or ‘piled up’, etc.), and this argument may be indexed by an \isi{object marker} preceding the form kuk ‘gather’. The place in(to) which things are being gathered or piled is, in turn, the object of the verb ‘put’, and thus occurs as an NP between the separable form kuk ‘gather’ and the \isi{verb stem} u- ‘put’, as in examples \REF{ex:phrase:81} and \REF{ex:phrase:82}.
Content 1: \gsrc Siwi \textbf{kuk} wa \textbf{nolnda}. | \gll siwi \textbf{kuk} wa na-\textbf{lu}-nda | \gls grub.species gather village DETR-put-IRR | \glt `[We] will gather grubs home.’\footnote{Note the \isi{metathesis} of the alternate form [lu-] of the \isi{verb stem} lï- ‘put’
Content 2: \gsrc Mï \textbf{ndïkuk} nïn ani \textbf{mope}. | \gll mï ndï=\textbf{kuk} nï=n ani ma=\textbf{u-}p-e | \gls 3SG.SUBJ 3PL=gather 1SG=OBL bilum 3SG.OBJ=put-PFV-DEP | \glt `She piled them into my bilum [= string bag].’

Subsection: The verbs u- ‘put’, lï- ‘put’, and lumo- ‘put’\label{sec:9.2.2
Knowledge Point: As a \isi{phonotactic}ally prohibited word-final \isi{consonant} (\sectref{sec:2.1.1}), the final [k] in kuk ‘gather’ may be \isi{deleted} when this word occurs as a separate form \REF{ex:phrase:83}.\footnote{The \isi{nominal adjunct}s in \isi{separable verb} constructions such as this one may be forms that occur only in verbal \isi{compound}s -- that is, unlike lïmndï ‘eye’, which occurs frequently as a noun in its own right (e.g., mï nïnji lïmndï masap ‘he hit my eye’), there is no indication that forms like kuk ‘gather’ (or ‘gathering’?), ever appear on their own without such verbs.}
Content 1: \gsrc Nïpïl ndïwale \textbf{ndïku} inim \textbf{awe}. | \gll nïpïl ndï=wali-e ndï=\textbf{kuk} inim \textbf{aw}-e | \gls vine 3PL=hit-IPFV 3PL=gather water put.IPFV-DEP | \glt `[We] used to break vines and gather them into the water.’

Subsection: The verbs u- ‘put’, lï- ‘put’, and lumo- ‘put’\label{sec:9.2.2
Knowledge Point: Other \isi{separable verb}s with \isi{stem}s meaning ‘put’ have as their first elements words that seem less likely to permit \isi{object marker}s. For example, tane ‘stand’ has as its object the place where one stands, and this is marked on the ‘put’ verb, rather than on the form tane ‘stand’. In \REF{ex:phrase:84}, this \isi{locative} argument is expressed by the \isi{object-marker} \isi{proclitic} ma= ‘\textsc{3sg.obj}’, which in this \isi{phrase} has the sense ‘there’.
Content 1: \gsrc Ngala imba pe \textbf{tane malpe}. | \gll ngala imba p-e \textbf{tane} ma=\textbf{lï}-p-e | \gls PL.PROX night be{-dep} stand 3SG.OBJ=put-PFV-DEP | \glt `These people stand there at night.’

Subsection: The verbs u- ‘put’, lï- ‘put’, and lumo- ‘put’\label{sec:9.2.2
Knowledge Point: That said, this verb can at times permit two objects -- that is, the first element may permit as an object that which is stood (i.e., erected, positioned, etc.), as in \REF{ex:phrase:85}.
Content 1: \gsrc I apa kongomlïp mat i \textbf{matanelïp}. | \gll i apa ko=angom-lï-p ma=tï i ma=\textbf{tane-lï}-p | \gls go.PFV house INDF=pull.out-put-PFV 3SG.OBJ=take go.PFV 3SG.OBJ=stand-put-PFV | \glt `[It] went and pulled out a house, brought it, and stood it up.’

Subsection: The verbs u- ‘put’, lï- ‘put’, and lumo- ‘put’\label{sec:9.2.2
Knowledge Point: There are some other verbs that appear on \isi{morphological} grounds to belong to this class of separable ‘put’ verbs, but which never seem to occur as \isi{discontinuous} elements. This could simply be due to their \isi{semantics}. For example, the object of a verb such as mïmïlu- ‘wring, strain’ is more likely to be a \isi{theme} argument than a \isi{goal} argument. This verb may be seen in sentences \REF{ex:phrase:86} and \REF{ex:phrase:87}.\footnote{The fact that ‘put’ verbs can, however, so commonly permit separable constructions has a certain rationale to it, especially considering that the object of these verbs glossed as ‘put’ is always the \isi{goal} and not the \isi{theme}, which, when overt, is expressed as an \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase}. Thus, in expressions like ‘send to a place’ or ‘gather/pile up to a place’, it is appropriate that the object of the second element in the \isi{separable verb} (i.e., the ‘put’ verb) is a destination.}
Content 1: \gsrc Ulum tamndï mawa \textbf{ndïmïmïlunda}. | \gll ulum tamndï ma-awa ndï=\textbf{mïmïl-u}-nda | \gls palm owner 3SG.OBJ-INT 3PL=wring-put-IRR | \glt `The owner of the sago palms herself will wring them.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndï \textbf{ndïmïmïlawe}. | \gll ndï ndï=\textbf{mïmïl-aw}-e | \gls 3PL 3PL=wring-put.IPFV-DEP | \glt `They would be wringing them.’

Knowledge Point: Members of the class of ka- ‘let’ \isi{separable verb}s tend to be \isi{intransitive}. When they do take objects, however, these are \isi{goal} arguments, much like their counterparts in ‘put’ \isi{separable verb}s (\sectref{sec:9.2.2}). These objects occur between the first element and the \isi{verb stem}. Examples \REF{ex:phrase:88} through \REF{ex:phrase:93} illustrate some uses of \isi{verb phrase}s formed with ka- ‘let’.
Content 1: \gsrc Nawa ndul \textbf{asike} ndï matap. | \gll nï-awa ndï=ul \textbf{asi-ka}-e ndï ma=ta-p | \gls 1SG-INT 3PL=with sit-let{-dep} 3PL 3SG.OBJ=say-PFV | \glt `I myself sat with them, and they talked about it.’
Content 2: \gsrc Una \textbf{tïkli} \textbf{amblalaka} wolka amblawalinda man. | \gll unan \textbf{tïkli} ambla=la-\textbf{ka} wolka ambla=wali-nda ma-n | \gls 1PL.INCL turn PL.REFL=IRR-let again PL.REFL=hit-IRR go-IPFV | \glt `We’re going to turn on one another and fight one another again.’

Knowledge Point: Often, however, instead of being expressed as the \isi{direct object} of the verb, the \isi{goal} argument in such constructions is expressed in a \isi{postpositional phrase}. Still, these phrases occur between the first element of the \isi{separable verb} and the \isi{verb stem}, as in \REF{ex:phrase:94}, \REF{ex:phrase:95}, and \REF{ex:phrase:96}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{asi} unji komblam mayn \textbf{ka}. | \gll nï \textbf{asi} u-nji komblam ma=in \textbf{ka} | \gls 1SG sit 2SG-POSS chair 3SG.OBJ=in let | \glt `I sat in your chair.’
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Lop} ndïkana \textbf{ka} ko nip. | \gll \textbf{lop} ndï=kana \textbf{ka} ko ni-p | \gls lie 3PL=beside let just die-PFV | \glt `[She] lay beside them and just died.’

Knowledge Point: Most \isi{postpositional phrase}s consist of just a single \isi{postposition}. However, it is also possible for multiple \isi{postposition}s to occur within a single \isi{phrase}, sharing a single object. This use of multiple \isi{postposition}s often conveys a specific (usually spatial) relationship between two NPs. A common component of such complex \isi{postpositional phrase}s is u ‘from, in, at, around, along’, which, when following another \isi{postposition}, may add to it an \isi{ablative} sense, as in examples \REF{ex:phrase:97} through \REF{ex:phrase:100}.\footnote{An alternative analysis might be that at least some of these putative \isi{postposition}s are (or can function as) nouns. Thus, what is translated as ‘from atop the table’ in \REF{ex:phrase:97} may perhaps be better translated as ‘from the table’s top’.}
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{aplatam mawat u} ani matïn. | \gll nï \textbf{aplatam} \textbf{ma=wat} \textbf{u} ani ma=tï-n | \gls 1SG table 3SG.OBJ=atop from bilum 3SG.OBJ=take-PFV | \glt `I took the bilum [= string bag] from atop the table.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ndin u} siwi lomoke. | \gll \textbf{ndï=in} \textbf{u} siwi ala=moko-e | \gls 3PL=in from grub.species PL.DIST=take-IPFV | \glt `[He] would get grubs from within them.’
Content 3: \gsrc Nï \textbf{aplatam mawat u} ani matïn. | \gll nï \textbf{aplatam} \textbf{ma=wat} \textbf{u} ani ma=tï-n | \gls 1SG table 3SG.OBJ=atop from bilum 3SG.OBJ=take-PFV | \glt `I took the bilum [= string bag] from atop the table.’

Knowledge Point: Sometimes, however, two \isi{postposition}s may occur in a single \isi{phrase} without any sense of \isi{motion}. In \REF{ex:phrase:101}, the two \isi{postposition}s wan ‘over, above’ and wat ‘atop, onto’ combine to give the sense of something hovering above something else.
Content 1: \gsrc Yangun mï \textbf{aplatam mawan wat} wap. | \gll yangun mï \textbf{aplatam} \textbf{ma=wan} \textbf{wat} wap | \gls mosquito 3SG.SUBJ table 3SG.OBJ=above atop be.PST | \glt `The mosquito was above the table.’

Knowledge Point: It is even possible for three \isi{postposition}s to occur within a single \isi{phrase}, as demonstrated by examples \REF{ex:phrase:102} and \REF{ex:phrase:103}.
Content 1: \gsrc Yangun mï \textbf{aplatam mawan wat u} mbi. | \gll yangun mï \textbf{aplatam} \textbf{ma=wan} \textbf{wat} \textbf{u} mbï-i | \gls mosquito 3SG.SUBJ table 3SG.OBJ=above atop from here-go.PFV | \glt `The mosquito came from above the table.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nongami \textbf{mawan wat u} molop. | \gll Nongami \textbf{ma=wan} \textbf{wat} \textbf{u} ma=lo-p | \gls [name] 3SG.OBJ=above atop from 3SG.OBJ=cut-PFV | \glt `Nongami cut it from above it.’

Knowledge Point: These PPs consisting of multiple \isi{postposition}s should not be confused with series of multiple PPs occurring within a single clause. The latter construction type always contains multiple objects (one per \isi{head postposition} in each PP), as in \REF{ex:phrase:104} and \REF{ex:phrase:105}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Maya} al \textbf{men} i. | \gll ma=\textbf{iya} al ma=\textbf{in} i | \gls 3SG.OBJ=toward net 3SG.OBJ=in go.PFV | \glt `[It] went to him into [his] mosquito net.’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: First, when multiple \isi{adjective}s modify the same \isi{head noun}, it is not clear whether one or another \isi{adjective} has a closer affinity to the \isi{head noun}. In other words, it is not clear what the constituent structure is. An example of a noun being modified by multiple \isi{adjective}s is given in \REF{ex:phrase:106}.
Content 1: \gsrc lamndu ambi anma mï | \gll lamndu ambi anma mï | \gls pig big good 3SG.SUBJ | \glt (a) ‘the big [good pig]’

Knowledge Point: Second, when an NP has multiple \isi{predicate adjective}s, it may be most parsimonious to analyze them as \isi{coordinate}d \isi{paratactic}ally, since Ulwa does not contain overt \isi{coordinator}s (\sectref{sec:12.1}). Such an analysis is employed for sentences such as \REF{ex:phrase:107}.
Content 1: \gsrc Lamndu mï ambi anma. | \gll lamndu mï ambi anma | \gls pig 3SG.SUBJ big good | \glt `The pig is big [and] good.’

Knowledge Point: Third, when one \isi{adjective} in a series is functioning as a substantive, it may indeed be the \isi{head} of a \isi{phrase} -- but this \isi{phrase} in question is a \isi{noun phrase}, not an \isi{adjectival phrase}, as illustrated by \REF{ex:phrase:108} and \REF{ex:phrase:109}.
Content 1: \gsrc ambi anma mï | \gll ambi anma mï | \gls big good 3SG.SUBJ | \glt `the good big [one]’
Content 2: \gsrc Ambi (mï) anma. | \gll ambi (mï) anma | \gls big (3SG.SUBJ) good | \glt `The big [one] is good.’
